title: 112_hr3139
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" and establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The Act establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, which includes provisions for contributions, gross income, and distributions related to natural disaster protection funds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act introduces provisions for distributions from natural disaster protection funds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifying that certain distributions are not included in gross income if returned before the filing of the tax return for the taxable year. The term 'natural disaster protection fund' refers to money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account, invested according to District of Columbia laws. The term 'qualified insurance company' in the District of Columbia must meet specific investment requirements and be subject to supervision by the Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking. The qualified insurance company in the District of Columbia must meet certain criteria, including maintaining an office with a minimum number of employees who are residents of the District, being subject to various taxes and fees imposed by the District, and potentially facing additional taxes on premiums for natural catastrophic risk coverage. The text discusses the definition of a "qualified contribution" and a "qualified distribution" in relation to a fund established by a qualified insurance company for coverage of qualified losses. The contribution should not exceed the amount at risk for the payment of losses insured through the fund, less reinsurance on those risks. The text defines "qualified distribution" as payments for qualified losses, including insurance payments, risk spreading, balance drawdown, administrative expenses, and claims investigation. A "qualified loss" is an insured loss on a US risk caused by events like wind or hurricanes. The text outlines events that qualify as insured losses, including wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, pandemic, or public health catastrophe. Insured losses must meet certain criteria, such as total insured losses from the event. The text outlines events that qualify as insured losses, including wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, pandemic, or public health catastrophe. Insured losses must meet certain criteria, such as exceeding $1,000,000,000 on an industry-wide basis, presidential or gubernatorial disaster declarations, and catastrophic industry-wide loss declarations by Property Claims Services unit. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the excess amount in certain situations. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the excess of the fund balance over the total exposure to qualified losses. 'United States risk' refers to hazards or liabilities in the US or its territories. Premiums and losses on Puerto Rican risks covered by a catastrophe reserve are excluded from calculations. The regulations of Puerto Rico are not considered in determining qualified contributions or losses. Contributions in kind to a fund are treated as a sale or exchange at fair market value. Distributions in kind to a qualified insurance company are treated similarly. The Secretary will establish necessary regulations for this subsection. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for carrying out the purposes of this subsection regarding additional tax on certain distributions from a natural disaster protection fund for qualified insurance companies. The tax imposed will be increased by 20 percent of nonqualified distributions from the fund. The bill defines terms related to natural disaster protection funds and qualified insurance companies. The amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
